summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing FOIA requests and Touhy requests related to Jeffrey Epstein. It centers on the New York Times filing a FOIA complaint against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and the internal coordination for handling requests from civil plaintiffs/victims for information from the government's criminal investigation.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Named as the attorney for plaintiffs (alleged victims) in civil litigation related to Epstein, to whom the Civil Division will communicate regarding Touhy request procedures.

events.title: NY Times Files FOIA Complaint Against BOP
events.description: The New York Times files a FOIA complaint challenging the Bureau of Prisons' response (or lack thereof) to the Times's FOIA requests for records related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Coordination on Epstein-Related Touhy Requests
events.description: Internal discussion memorializing that a Civil Division AUSA will be the point person for Touhy requests from civil plaintiffs/victims in Epstein lawsuits, with criminal AUSAs providing support due to their knowledge of the case.

keyFacts: The New York Times filed a FOIA complaint against the Bureau of Prisons for failing to adequately respond to requests for Jeffrey Epstein-related records.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York established an internal protocol where a Civil Division AUSA would handle communications for Touhy requests from Epstein civil plaintiffs, while criminal AUSAs would do the substantive work due to their familiarity with the case.
Plaintiff's counsel Robbie Kaplan of Kaplan & Hecker is identified as a point of contact for civil litigation by alleged victims.
The document includes detailed draft language explaining the Touhy regulations governing disclosure of information from DOJ investigations for use in unrelated litigation.
The response highlights legal privileges that may block disclosure, including the law enforcement privilege protecting confidential sources, investigatory records, and techniques.
